Graphical abstract Feasible presodiation is indispensable in improving the energy density, lifespan and rate performance of sodium ion batteries. In this contribution, the fundamentals and advancements of presodiation methodology are comprehensively interpreted, encompassing the properties, underlying principles, associated approaches, and corresponding optimizations to present technological inferiorities. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are expected to offer affordability and high energy density for large-scale energy storage system. However, the commercial application of SIBs is hurdled by low initial coulombic efficiency (ICE), continuous Na loss during long-term operation, and low sodium-content of cathode materials. In this scenario, presodiation strategy by introducing an external sodium reservoir has been rationally proposed, which could supplement additional sodium ions into the system and thereby markedly improve both the cycling performance and energy density of SIBs. In this review, the significance of presodiation is initially introduced, followed by comprehensive interpretation on technological properties, underlying principles, and associated approaches, as well as our perspectives on present inferiorities and future research directions. Overall, this contribution outlines a distinct pathway towards the presodiation methodology, of significance but still in its nascent phase, which may inspire the targeted guidelines to explore new chemistry in this field. Keywords Presodiation Increased coulombic efficiency High reversible capacity Sodium ion batteries 1 Introduction The irreversible damage to earth and increasing concerns on exhaustion of fossil energy have stimulated research interests for clean and sustainable sources (such as solar, wind, tidal energy, etc.), where energy storage systems (EES) are essential credited to the fluctuation feature of these sources [1–6]. Among various EES technologies, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are ideal candidate due to the unlimited resources and low cost. However, the high performance in terms of energy density and long-term stability have been challenged by low initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) and sodium deficiency (continuous loss or sodium-poor electrodes), which has greatly slowed down the industrialization of SIBs. Generally, the primary causes can be categorized as following: Na loss from the formation of passivation interface. The thermodynamic disequilibrium between the electrolyte and electrode (especially at the higher state of charge, SoC) always trigger the decomposition of electrolyte components [7–13], resulted in forming electrode-electrolyte interface (EEI) passivation films, including the so-called solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on the anode and cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI) on the cathode [14–17]. The EEI is a sodium containing mixture mainly composed of inorganic sodium salts (Na2CO3, NaO2, NaF, etc.) and organic sodium salt for instance, ROCO2Na (R is an organic group) [18]. Despite such passivation layer with high ionic conductivity and superior electronic insulation is beneficial for the performance to some extent [7,19–23], the initial formation and subsequent rupture/regeneration of EEI layers will consume plenty of active sodium ions [24,25], which is detrimental to ICE and lifespan. “Dead Na” during cycling. “Dead Na” always emerge up owing to side reactions and sluggish reaction kinetics, especially for the conversion-based metal oxides (such as Co3O4 [26], Fe3O4 [27], MnO [28], etc.) and metal sulfides (MoS2 [29], SnS2 [30], Sb2S3 [31], etc.). For these materials, the intermediate products of Na2O, Na2S with strong Na–O and Na–S bonds severely reduce the reversibility [32,33], resulting in a huge loss of active sodium. Moreover, the large volume change of the electrode material during the charging and discharging process causing the pulverization of the active material particles will continue to react with the electrolyte and thus consume the active sodium ions, leading to a rapid decay of capacity [34,35]. What’s more, ‘Trap effect’ is another reason for “Dead Na” during cycling in hard carbon (HC). ‘Trap effect’ means that defects including vacancies, heteroatoms, edges, and so on inside of graphene sheets of HC, where significant diffusion barriers and strong binding energy between defects and Na+ always cause a large proportion of irreversible capacity in the first cycle [23,36–38]. Sodium-poor electrodes. Transition metal oxides are considered to be promising cathodes for achieving high energy density SIBs because of high theoretical voltage, but the practical application have been hindered by several major drawbacks, including the low initial charging capacities such as for P2-type layered oxide materials (P2-type Na2/3Fe0.4Mn0.6O2 [39], P2-type Na0.67Ni0.15Mn0.85O2 [40], and P2-type Na2/3(Fe1/2Mn1/2)O2 [41]) and tunnel-type cathode (Na0.44MnO2 [42–44]), and metal dissolution during charging and discharging process. Therefore, how to increase the overall performance of SIBs remains a grand challenge [45]. To cope with the lingering Na loss in SIBs, pre-sodiation as a feasible strategy was thereby proposed and attracted considerable research interests [45]. Presodiation literally means pre-injecting an excess of active sodium ions into the battery system, to compensate for the loss of active ions in the initial charge/discharge and subsequent cycling (Fig. 1 ). After introducing an additional ion source, the electrochemical performance of SIBs, including energy density, cycle performance, and rate performance might be optimized [46–49]. Currently, there are three most conventional means, electrochemical presodiation (ECP), chemical presodiation (CP), and sacrificial salt presodiation (SSP), as schematically shown in Fig. 2 . Presodiation replenishing additional Na+ ion benefits the overall electrochemical performance of SIBs by many aspects of constructing EEI in advance, transforming sodium-poor cathodes, and increasing the energy density of full cell, as specifically summarized below. (i) Replenishing the irreversible capacity of the battery during the initial cycle. An additional sodium source is introduced to compensate for the loss of active ions during cycling, thus improving the energy density of full cell. (ii) Constructing EEI in advance. For anode materials, the SEI layer constructed by presodiation can not only significantly improve the ICE of anode materials but also alleviate the poor cycling stability, especially for the alloy anode with large volume changes. For cathodes, the priorly constructed CEI layer could alleviate the dissolution of active metals and reduce the irreversible loss of Na+ to improve reversible capacity [15]. (iii) Converting sodium-poor material into sodium-rich state. The intrinsically low sodium content of some compounds results in limited charge capacity. After effective presodiation, the sodium-poor cathode material (like Na0.44MnO2, Na3V2(PO4)3 and etc.) can be transformed into sodium-rich state thus the application scope were greatly broadened [1,50–52]. (iv) Beneficial for the fabrication of full-cells. For sodium ion full batteries, the optimal performance will be achieved only when capacity and efficiency are matched between cathode and anode. For instance, given the fact that alloy anode and carbon anode have low ICE compared to cathode, presodiation for such anodes could significantly improve the utilization degree of charge carrier and resulted in enhanced energy density [4,52]. In the paper, we present a comprehensive interpretation on the advancements in presodiation methodology, encompassing its properties, underlying principles, and associated approaches. In addition, corresponding optimizations to present technological inferiorities are highlighted as target-oriented guidelines for exploiting new chemistry in this field. 2 Presodiation for cathode 2.1 Electrochemical presodiation for cathodes Electrochemical presodiation of the cathode material means that a pre-discharge step is performed before assembling full-cells. Through such strategy of great significance, constructing of artificial CEI and sodiation of sodium-poor state materials could be achieved. The interphase side reactions and dissolution of active metals cause rapid capacity decay and poor cycling performance of the battery, which can be countered by constructing CEI layer on the surface of the cathode material. To be specific, the desired cathode is pre-operated to form a protective CEI layer from the decomposition of selected electrolyte, then the decorated cathode is refabricated into new cell to depress the electrolyte decomposition and transition metal dissolution. For instance, Iqra et al. fabricated a half-cell in configuration of Na0.67Fe0.5Ni0.5O2 as the working electrode and Na foil as the counter electrode [16]. During the pre-discharge operation, the electrolyte was reduced at 1.6 V with forming artificial CEI (ACEI) layer on the cathode surface. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), this artificially generated CEI layer is thicker and denser than the CEI layer formed naturally, which protected the electrode from the corrosive side reactions. In the subsequent electrochemical performance tests, presodiated Na0.67Fe0.5Ni0.5O2 (PS-NFNO) also showed better cycling stability of retaining 86% the original capacity after 50 cycles, much higher than that of 66% for the pristine Na0.67Fe0.5Ni0.5O2. In addition to the construction of the ACEI layer, sodium-rich cathode materials could also be controllably harvested by ECP strategy. Mirza et al. assembled Na3V2(PO4)3@C half-cell with a Na foil as counter electrode and converted Na3V2(PO4)3 to Na4V2(PO4)3 by conducting a constant current discharge process to 1 V versus Na/Na+ (Fig. 3b) [53]. The full-cell with hard carbon (HC) and Na4V2(PO4)3 cathode (HC||Na4V2(PO4)3@C) demonstrated that the prestored sodium ions could waive the irreversible Na loss during cycling entirely. More impressively, the HC||Na4V2(PO4)3@C demonstrated both higher ICE of 95.0% and excellent rate performance compared to the blank one (Fig. 3c). In addition to conducting a constant current discharge process for half-cells, electrochemical pre-sodiation can also be achieved via reduction process by contacting electrode with Na-foil with the presence of electrolyte. Wu et al. successfully achieved presodiating Na3V2(PO4)3 to Na5V2(PO4)3 by short-circuit presodiation process (Fig. 3d) [50]. The sodiation depth of Na3+ x V2(PO4)3 (0 ≤ x ≤ 2) can be monitored by measuring the open circuit voltage (OCV), and the experimental results showed that the fully sodiated Na5V2(PO4)3 could be obtained after merely 5 min treatment (Fig. 3e). However, ECP method does not match with current process of assembling battery and many tedious steps including disassembly of half-cells, cleaning electrodes and reassembling are required, make it difficult to achieve scalable applications in practical manner. 2.2 Chemical presodiation for cathodes The chemical presodiation method derives originally from prelithiation, which refers to the reduction of electrode by the strongly reducing chemical lithiation reagents. Early to 1998, Scott et al. successfully prelithiated carbon electrode with butyl lithium [54]. Further studies on common reducing agents unveiled that alkali metals can react spontaneously with polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) in ether solvents at room temperature, such as biphenyl lithium (Li-Biph) [55], naphthalene lithium (Li-Naph) [56]. Due to the identify working principles between the SIBs and LIBs, as well as similar physicochemical properties between Na and Li metal, various reductive chemical sodiation reagents were thereby proposed by the similar manner. Zhou et al. [43] prepared biphenyl sodium reagent by dissolving equal molar amounts of biphenyl (Biph) and sodium foil in 1, 2-Dimethoxyethane (DME) solvent. The concentration of reagent and treatment time must be strictly controlled because the cyclic voltammogram test of biphenyl sodium demonstrated that its reduction potential is as low as close to that of sodium metal (Fig. 4 a), that is, strong reductive capability. The application of this functional regent was performed on Na0.44MnO2, which is a low-cost and structurally stable cathode material but limited by the low charge capacity. Correspondingly, after simple immersing, the sodium-poor Na0.44MnO2 was reduced to sodium-rich Na0.66MnO2, along with the initial specific charging capacity increase of from 56.5 to 115 mA h g−1 (Fig. 4b). Roman R. Kapaev also successfully achieved sodiating Na3V2(PO4)3 to Na4V2(PO4)3 in the same way with phenazine sodium reagent, enhancing about 30 mA h g−1 in the initial charge process [51]. In addition to replenishing the sodium ions into the crystal lattice of cathode, Ye et al. [15] constructed in-situ CEI on the surface of Prussian blue (PB) by CP method based on the spontaneous redox reaction of Na-Biph and the binder (PVDF) on the electrode (Fig. 4c and d). The artificially constructed NaF-rich CEI layer containing Na-salts (NaF, Na2CO3, and NaHCO3) and organic Na-based species (R-O-Na, R-CO-Na, and R-O2CO-Na) is more uniform, thinner and stable compared to the CEI layer formed in the blank electrolyte. As a result, the artificial CEI with good electric conductivity and ionic mobility suppressed the undesirable parasitic reaction and ensured ultra-long cycling. Overall, chemical presodiation method is simple to operate thus has the potential for scalable applications due to its high efficiency. However, current presodiation reagents based mainly on PAHs with conjugated large Π–bonds always render strong reducibility towards cathodes, which could easily cause over-sodiation even structural damage for the treated cathodes. In this scenario, our group recently has proposed for the first time that introducing a carbonyl group (C=O) with inductive effect to change PAHs as aromatic ketones (AKs) could balance the strong conjugated effect, which opens a new avenue to the “mild presodiating reagents” towards cathodes. The mild presodiation reagents contain features of mild, stable and fast chemical presodiation, so the designed AKs can show moderate reduction ability during presodiation process, avoiding the structural damage of the treated cathode materials. 2.3 Presodiation of cathodes by sacrificial salts This straightforward strategy refers to the adding a small dose of sacrificial sodium-rich salt that is able to decompose and release sodium ions into the battery during charge. Note although the presodiation for cathodes by sacrificial salt involved an electrochemical oxidation step, which is always regarded as an independent approach versus the conventional ECP method that adopted a pre-reduction reaction [47–49]. The released sodium ions during oxidation reaction can then migrate into a directional manner between cathode and anode, and increase remarkably the energy density of the battery. Prevailing sacrificial salts can be roughly divided into two groups, including inorganics of NaN3, Na3P, Na2S, Na2O2, Na2CO3, Na2NiO2, NaNO2, NaCrO2, etc., and organic sacrificial salt additives of Na2C2O4, Na2C3O5, DTPA-5Na, EDTA-4Na, Na2C4O4, Na2C6O6 and so in forth [57–82], as summarized in Table 1 . 2.3.1 Inorganic sacrificial salts NaN3 with a high theoretical specific capacity of 412 mA h g−1 was first reported by Gurpreet Singh as the sodium reservoir for sodium-deficiency Na0.67[Fe0.5Mn0.5]O2 [57]. In the half-cell measurement, the irreversible capacity of Na0.67[Fe0.5Mn0.5]O2 with addition of 5 wt% NaN3 decreased to 27 mA h g−1 during the first cycle, which was half of the irreversible capacity in the pristine cathode. To further test the effect of NaN3 on the electrochemical system, full cells of hard carbon anode and Na0.67[Fe0.5Mn0.5]O2 containing NaN3 cathode were constructed and the ratio of NaN3 were investigated [59] (Fig. 5 a). However, it is worth mentioning that a significant capacity decay can be observed with the increase of NaN3 content, which was ascribed the irreversible destruction to the electrode structure because of the release of N2 from NaN3. Na2S is another additive extensively used for sodium ion capacitors (SICs) before [64]. Recently, the Na2S/C nanocomposite composed of ultrafine sodium sulfide clusters confined in carbon nanopolyhedrons with particle size of about 40 nm was tentatively used as the cathode sacrificial salt (Fig. 5b) [73]. This peculiar structure endowed multiple merits: the ultra-fine particle size ensures the fast reaction kinetics of the Na2S decomposition, and confining Na2S in the micropores of the carbon skeleton not only facilitated the electron transport but also avoided the dissolution of polysulfides into the electrolyte (Fig. 5c). Consequently, the as-treated Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode with 5 wt% Na2S nanocomposites delivered an enhanced initial charging specific capacity of 128 mA h g−1, much higher than that of 109 mA h g−1 from the pristine electrode. In addition to these primary sodium-containing inorganic sacrificial salts, some cathode materials with poor reversibility have also been used of novelty as sacrificial reagent. Xu et al. has demonstrated that there exists an irreversible phase transition of NaCrO2 in the high voltage range (>3.9 V), resulting in a high irreversible capacity of 229 mA h g−1 as depicted in Fig. 5(d) [65]. Unexpectedly, the HC||Na3V2O2(PO4)2F@NaCrO2 full-cell showed a specific capacity of 90 mA h g−1 with 80% capacity retention after 50 cycles, while the blank full-cell only delivered a capacity of 10.7 mA h g−1 after 50 cycles (Fig. 5e). Similarly, Park et al. reported the possibility of Na2NiO2 as an additive and proposed that Na2NiO2 is gradually irreversibly converted to NaNiO2 during the charge process [58]. The additional sodium ions provided by this irreversible phase transition compensate for the loss of sodium ions in the formation of EEI layer. The reversible capacity increased from 74.6 to 92 mA h g−1 when Na2NiO2 was incorporated into the full-cell with configuration of Sb/C anode and NaCrO2 cathode. 2.3.2 Organic sacrificial salts Most inorganic salts are not electroactive and need a high voltage to trigger the decomposition. In addition, some of the inorganic sacrificial salts have safety hazards such as explosiveness (e.g. Na2O2 [72], NaN3 [57,59]) and toxicity (e.g. Na3P [82]). In this scenario, organic sacrificial salts were attempted in the low-cost and environmentally friendly manner due to the fact that abundant organic salts could be prepared by the precursors of natural organic acids. As the typical small molecule organic salt, sodium oxalate (Na2C2O4) has been considered as one of the most promising sacrificial salts credited to merits of high theoretical specific capacity (400 mA h g−1) and low cost [69]. In the practical half-cell test, it could deliver a specific capacity of 395 mA h g−1 with a capacity utilization of 99% when charged to 4.5 V. However, its average decomposition voltage (4.41 V) is much higher than its theoretical decomposition voltage (1.974 V) because of its low electronic conductivity, which poses a huge challenge for electrolytes and electrode materials. To suppress the decomposition overpotential of Na2C2O4, conductive carbon with different specific surface areas and dosage were exploited. For instance, the decomposition voltage could be reduced to 4.11 V (with KB) and 3.97 V (with CMK-3), and the electrochemical performance of the full-cell based on hard carbon anode and P2-Na2/3Ni1/3Mn1/3Ti1/3O2 cathode with Na2C2O4 (10 wt%) were improved substantially [71]. The possibility of sodium mesoxalate (Na2C3O5) with similar chain-like structure of Na2C2O4 has been by studied by Devaraj, and a lower decomposition voltage of 4.0 V was unveiled [71]. Consequently, in addition to compensating for the sodium loss, the capacity retention of SIBs was greatly improved due to the formation of a thinner and more stable CEI on the surface of P2-Na2/3Mn0.8Fe0.1Ti0.1O2 when Na2C3O5 was incorporated (Fig. 6 a). Moreover, the specific capacity was fourfold enlarged compared to the pristine one in the sodium-ion full cells (SIFCs) with hard carbon anode [71]. In addition to chain-compounds mentioned above, carbonated cyclic organic salts of the Na2C n O n (n = 3–6) family are another group of promising sacrificial salts. The possibility of sodium squarate (Na2C4O4) with its theoretical specific capacity up to 339 mA h g−1 has been extensively explored [60,63,66,74]. Devaraj et al. explored the mechanism of Na2C4O4 and demonstrated that it decomposed at 3.6 V along with the releasing Na+ and CO2 [60]. Shen's group prepared composite cathode of Na3(VOPO4)2F@KB-Na2C4O4 and unveiled the addition of Na2C4O4 not only increased charging capacity of the cell in the first cycle, but also greatly improved the rate performance and cycling stability [66]. Similarly, Elena Marelli employed sodium rhodizonate (Na2C6O6) with theoretical specific capacity of 250 mA h g−1 as a sacrificial salt to achieve the presodiation of Na0.67Mn0.6Fe0.25Co0.15O2 [79]. Tang further successfully prepared more Na-content Na4C6O6 by annealing Na2C6O6 at 400 °C under Ar atmosphere for 2 h, increasing its theoretical specific capacity from 250 to 412 mA h g−1. The scheme of the Na4C6O6 decompensation mechanism shown in Fig. 6(b) indicates that substantial Na ions released during the initial charge process to replenish the sodium loss in full-cell [78]. In order to extend the family of organic sacrificial salts, some nitrogen-containing chelating agents were studied consecutively. Jo et al. conducted an in-depth study on using sodium edetate (EDTA-4Na) [62] and diethylene triaminepentaacetic acid pentasodium salt (DTPA-5Na) [68] as sacrificial salts. By adding EDTA-4Na to P2-type Na0.67[Al0.05Mn0.95]O2, the charging specific capacity of the composite electrode increased from 83 to 177 mA h g−1. Similarly, the specific capacity of Na0.44MnO2 changed from 58 to 128 mA h g−1 with DTPA-5Na employed. It’s confirmed that the addition of EDTA-4Na and DTPA-5Na could overcome the irreversible loss of sodium ions enhancing the overall capacity, and improve the cycling stability of full-cells as well. Interestingly, the decomposition of the sacrificial salt leads to generating high conductivity C3N deposits on the electrode surface (Fig. 6c), which polished the surface during the subsequent cycling and multiplicity tests. As this SSP methodology matches well with the current battery assembly process, it is intensively explored aimed for practical application [46]. After rational analysis, here we propose the following brief principles for the selection of cathode sacrificial additives. (1) Moderate working voltage. The decomposition voltage of the sacrificial salt should be lower than the oxidation limit of either cathode or electrolyte. Meanwhile, it should completely decompose and release all sodium ions in the first cycle of charging process. (2) High sodium contribution efficiency. The sacrificial salt should hold a large sodium content within the molecular, delivering more capacity to replenish sodium ions. (3) The products and residues after the decomposition of the sacrificial salt should have negligible impact on the overall performance. (4) The sacrificial salt should be inexpensive, nontoxic, explosion-resistant, stable in ambient atmosphere. In short, the effectiveness and feasibility of sacrificial salts have profound impact on the application and commercialization of SIBs, which may be one the most potential presodiation method for both research and industrial community. 3 Presodiation of anode Usually, anode electrodes in SIBs have higher specific capacity than that of cathodes, however, they also hindered severely by low ICE and poor cyclicity (especially for alloy and conversion anodes), caused mainly by the irreversible growth of SEI and the rupture/regeneration of SEI during cycling. Correspondingly, presodiation strategy was adopted as one feasible way to address these drawbacks. 3.1 Electrochemical presodiation for anode Identical to the treatment for cathode, electrochemical presodiation for anode can be achieved by performing a discharge process or conducting a rapid short-circuit with Na foil as the counter electrode before disassembly. The protective SEI layer can be constructed in advance on the surface, thus increase the reversible capacity of the full-cell. For instance, it is reported that the irreversible capacity of the HC was completely eliminated and the full-cell with a presodiated HC (PS-HC) anode showed enhanced performance of 131 mA h g−1, while the full-cell with a pristine HC only delivered a reversible capacity of 106 mA h g−1 [83]. Similarly, Zhou et al. achieved an enhanced energy density of from 134 Wh Kg−1 to 150 Wh Kg−1 in another full-cells of phosphorus/carbon//Na3V2(PO4)3 by the same treatment method [84]. In addition to a pre-discharge process, electrochemical presodiation can also be achieved by direct-contact method by performing a rapid short-circuit step via contacting electrode with Na foil in the presence of electrolyte. During the process of short-circuit, a dense SEI layer will form spontaneously due to the potential deviation between the sodium foil and the anode electrode, which has been extensively used for presodiating intercalation carbonaceous materials [85–88], transition metal oxide based on alloy and conversion reactions [86,89,90]. Zhang et al. obtained presodiated compositional hard carbon/graphene (HCG) anode by attaching Na foil with HCG electrode directly for designated time [85]. Consequently, the ICE of presodiated HCG increased to 99.1% while that was only 61.4% for the untreated one. Moeez et al. obtained presodiated HC and Na0.67Fe0.5Mn0.5O2 in the same way, and the full cell composed of PS-HC||PS-Na0.67Fe0.5Mn0.5O2 showed better cycling stability and higher reversible capacity [86]. In short, both the two electrochemical presodiation methods (pre-discharge and direct-contact) could achieve the depth of presodiation for the anodes. However, the former one is difficult to be applied at scalable level owing to its complex operation process, and for the latter, issues of inhomogeneous presodiation and metal residuals still need further inspections. 3.2 Chemical presodiation for anode Chemical presodiation for anode can be achieved by immersing the anode electrode into strong reductivity sodiation reagents, in which the degree of presodiation can be controlled by adjusting the concentration of the sodiating reagent and the reaction time. This method has been exploited on various carbon anodes [91–94], titanium-based anode [94], and alloy anodes [95,96]. For instance, Liu et al. prepared Na-Bp-DME by mixing equimolar amounts of biphenyl (Bp) and sodium metal in DME solvent [92]. In term of the large potential mismatch between HC and Na-Bp, HC accepted electrons from Bp-radical while incorporating Na+ to form Na x HC along with forming a SEI film on the surface of electrode (Fig. 7 a). Subsequent electrochemical measurements also witnessed substantial improvements of ICE in half-cell Na||Na x HC increasing from 70% to 100%, and energy density of full cell of Na x HC||Na3V2(PO4)3 enhancing to 218 Wh kg−1. In same manner, Sun et al. obtained Na-Naph reagent by dissolving equimolar amounts of naphthalene (Naph) and sodium metal in tetrahydrofuran (THF) and presodiated HC with Na-Naph solution spraying (Fig. 7b) [91]. Note this is different to above mentioned direct-contact method because of absence of electrolyte, thus free of short-circuit step. Undoubtedly, these polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (i.e., Bp, Naph) are strong enough to reduce the titanium-based anode with moderate working potential than HC. For instance, Cao et al. achieved chemical presodiation of TiO2 and Na2Ti3O7 with Na-Biph reagent, completely eliminating irreversible capacity loss and achieving nearly 100% ICE in the first cycle [94]. In order to alleviate the problems of low conservation efficiency and poor cycling stability of alloy anode, the feasibility of chemical presodiation has also been applied. Song et al. successfully presodiated red P-based (P/C@S) anode with Na-Bp to lower its equilibrium potential [96], which has induced the reduction of fluoroethylene carbonate to form a uniform NaF-rich SEI layer after further reaction (Fig. 7c). Impressively, the treated P/C@S anode showed versatility to couple with various cathodes regarding Na3V2(PO4)2F3, Na3V2(PO4)3, and NaCu0.12Ni0.23Fe0.33Mn0.33O2, indicating priority of this modified chemical presodiation method. The liquid sodiation reagent can infiltrate well the electrode materials, enabling more uniform presodiation compared to direct contact method. Nevertheless, the strong reductivity of aromatic chemical presodiation reagents requires for additional cautions to avoid over-sodiation. 4 Other prototype strategies Presodiation by physical method. This refers to the direct contact of electrode material with reducing agents like sodium metal without the presence of Na+-containing electrolyte. By the scalable ball-milling with reducing agents, Zhang et al. fulfilled the sodiation layered oxides and polyanionic compounds, i.e., P2-Na0.67[Fe0.5Mn0.5]O2 to P’2-Na[Fe0.5Mn0.5]O2 and Na3V2(PO4)2F3 to Na4V2(PO4)2F3 [82]. It is worth mentioning that the value of x in Na3 +x V2(PO4)2F3 can be adjusted by properly controlling the amounts of Na and ball milling time. Although sodium-rich cathode materials can be feasibly prepared in this way, the non-uniform solid-solid reaction during ball-milling and extreme sensitivity of Na metal remain grand challenges. Synthesis of high Na-content materials. Hu et al. proposed a new presodiation strategy to adopt quenching cooling instead of natural cooling procedure to synthesize the layered O3 type Na0.9Cu0.11Ni0.11Fe0.30Mn0.48Ti0.10O2 [97]. The quenching material maintains higher Mn3+ and Na+ content than that from natural cooling samples, thereby provides additional charge compensation for the irreversible sodium loss during the process of forming initial SEI (Fig. 8 a). The full-cells based on treated cathode and hard carbon exhibited 8% improvement in capacity retention after 300 cycles (Fig. 8b). Yet, the applicable scope of this method is strongly independent on cathode compositions. Passivating the irreversible reactive sites. Mao et al. converted g-C3N4 into B, N, and Na co-doped carbon by annealing g-C3N4 and NaBH4 under argon atmosphere (Fig. 8c) [98]. Pre-incorporated sodium passivates the irreversible reactive sites, which enhanced the ICE and energy density. For instance, the modified carbon material demonstrated a desirable ICE as high as 96.1%. This study introduces an innovative approach for achieving the presodiation during the synthesis process, offering fresh insights into optimizing the capacity of carbonaceous materials. 5 Summary and perspectives By introducing an external sodium reservoir, feasible presodiation is indispensable in improving the energy density, lifespan and rate performance of SIBs. In this contribution, we summarized the working principles and recent advances of prevailing applicable methods regarding electrochemical presodiation (ECP), chemical presodiation (CP), and sacrificial salt presodiation (SSP). ECP could be fulfilled by either predischarge or direct-contact in the presence of electrolyte. The degree of sodiation could be flexibly controlled in ECP, providing enclosed opportunities to investigate the detailed presodiation mechanisms. However, compared to CP and SSP, the cumbersome disassembly and reassembly procedures confine this method suitable to laboratory research but difficult to be applied into large-scale situation. CP method based on spontaneous chemical reaction from the strong reductive capability of liquid sodiation reagents could ensure the adequate and homogeneous presodiation of both cathode and anode materials. Nonetheless, several critical issues remain unresolved, necessitating further efforts regarding these aspects. i. The unstable physical/chemical properties. Present organic solvents need further optimization due to the low boiling point, flammability, as well as air instability. ii. Limited application scope from electrochemical activity. The strong reductivity of prevailing polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon is applicable to treatment anode materials working in low-voltage region, but will easily cause over-sodiation and even destroy the lattice structure of cathodes working in high-voltage window. Therefore, more “mild sodiating agents” towards cathodes are urgent, for instance, aromatic ketones with balanced conjugated and inductive effect proposed recently by our group [99]. iii. Inferior post procedures. The residuals after CP treatment may affect the overall performance of SIBs in the long-term operation, thus post procedures like cleaning and washing may necessary, however, relevant knowledge to this issue is still inferior at present. While for SSP, we suppose it as the most viable method to be commercially and scalarly utilized due to merits of simplicity of operation, high effectiveness of sodium supply and compatibility with current battery assembly line. Nevertheless, further efforts are required to i. Low voltage of decomposition. Current sacrificial salts are lingered by high decomposition voltage due to their poor electrochemical activeness and low ionic conductivity, which causes additional energy input and undesired side reactions from the electrolyte and electrode. To reduce the decomposition voltage of sacrificial salts except for the conductive carbon incorporation, the other attempt strategy is adopting catalysts, to reduce the activation energy of the decomposition reaction and enhance the ionic conductivity. ii. Inferior post procedures. Similar to that of above CP, the influence of side products like released gases and residuals after SSP treatment are not well unveiled so far. Based on our lab works and industrial experience, the released gas from sacrificial salts can be pumped out during the aging process. In addition, some pre-measures may also feasible, for instance, pre-encapsulating the sacrificial salt in carbon framework to isolate solid residues into electrolyte to reduce their detrimental effects. Overall, although the feasibility of presodiation strategy for enhanced electrochemical performance has been tentatively confirmed, this technology is still in its nascent phase and more endeavors are required to access advanced SIBs. Shihao Zhang received his B.S degree (2021) from Zhengzhou University. Now, he is pursuing the Ph.D. degree at College of Chemistry and Molecular Science, Wuhan University. His research interests focus on the presodiation strategy for sodium ion batteries. Xiangjun Pu obtained his Ph.D. in electrochemical engineering from Wuhan University in 2021. He used to be a visiting scholar in Prof. Chunsheng Wang’s group at University of Maryland, College Park of United States. Now he worked as a joint-postdoc between The Hong Kong Polytechnic University (host supervisor: Dr. Zheng-long Xu) of HKSA and Seoul National University of South Korea (host supervisor: Prof. Kisuk Kang). His research interests focus on fundamental electrochemistry and sustainable materials for lithium/sodium ion batteries. Chunhua Song used to be a postdoctoral fellow in Wuhan university under the supervision of Prof. Yuliang Cao during the period of 2014 to 2017. He currently holds the position of associate president of Zonergy Corporation Co., Ltd. based in Zigong, as well as the director and chief scientist of the company's Chengdu Institute affiliate. Yuliang Cao received his PhD (2003) in Wuhan University, and then he worked as a visiting scholar in Pacific Northwest National Laboratory from 2009 to 2011. He is now a professor at physical chemistry, Wuhan University. His research interests focus on developing advanced materials and novel electrolytes for lithium/sodium ion batteries.

coredata.dc:description: Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are expected to offer affordability and high energy density for large-scale energy storage system. However, the commercial application of SIBs is hurdled by low initial coulombic efficiency (ICE), continuous Na loss during long-term operation, and low sodium-content of cathode materials. In this scenario, presodiation strategy by introducing an external sodium reservoir has been rationally proposed, which could supplement additional sodium ions into the system and thereby markedly improve both the cycling performance and energy density of SIBs. In this review, the significance of presodiation is initially introduced, followed by comprehensive interpretation on technological properties, underlying principles, and associated approaches, as well as our perspectives on present inferiorities and future research directions. Overall, this contribution outlines a distinct pathway towards the presodiation methodology, of significance but still in its nascent phase, which may inspire the targeted guidelines to explore new chemistry in this field.
